articles.headline: Facebook Revenue Surpasses Forecasts
articles.snippet: The social network’s shares rose in after-hours trading, despite a net loss, as sales and earnings beat expectations.
articles.abstract: The social network’s shares rose in after-hours trading, despite a net loss, as sales and earnings beat expectations.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, told Wall Street on Tuesday that his company was on its way to cracking the mobile puzzle.

articles.headline: Better Ways to Deal With China
articles.snippet: Publicly getting tough with China over its currency to try to cut our trade deficit may not be a terribly productive approach.
articles.abstract: Publicly getting tough with China over its currency to try to cut our trade deficit may not be a terribly productive approach.
articles.lead_paragraph: Less than a year into a new administration, the nation’s trade deficit is soaring. Manufacturers are complaining bitterly that an overvalued dollar is destroying the economy, driving businesses abroad. Congress is bubbling with proposals to punish countries that are flooding the United States with cheaper exports.

articles.headline: Bigger Than Either of Them?
articles.snippet: This presidential campaign, like that in 2008, has framed energy as an issue that not only encompasses concerns about the environment and national security, but now economic revival.
articles.abstract: This presidential campaign, like that in 2008, has framed energy as an issue that not only encompasses concerns about the environment and national security, but now economic revival.
articles.lead_paragraph: “DRILL, baby, drill.” It is among the best-remembered lines of the 2008 presidential campaign, colorfully capturing the desire of many Americans for cheap, reliable energy produced at home rather than in unpredictable places like Iran or Venezuela.

articles.headline: Safety Becomes a Concern With High-Caffeine Drinks
articles.snippet: As consumption of energy drinks soars in the United States, critics say the Food and Drug Administration has allowed the drinks to languish in a regulatory gray area.
articles.abstract: As consumption of energy drinks soars in the United States, critics say the Food and Drug Administration has allowed the drinks to languish in a regulatory gray area.
articles.lead_paragraph: Among the latest entrants in the energy industry’s caffeine race is a pocket-size squeeze bottle called Mio Energy.

articles.headline: Sleek Tablet, but Clumsy Software
articles.snippet: In its Surface tablet, Microsoft wanted to build a device just as good at creating work as it is at organizing it. The hardware is brilliant, but the software is another story.
articles.abstract: In its Surface tablet, Microsoft wanted to build a device just as good at creating work as it is at organizing it. The hardware is brilliant, but the software is another story.
articles.lead_paragraph: How would you like to move into a stunning mansion on a bluff overlooking the sea — in Somalia? Or would you like the chance to own a new Ferrari — that has to be refueled every three miles? Would you take a job that pays $1 million a year — cutting football fields with toenail clippers?

articles.headline: In Cyberattack on Saudi Firm, U.S. Sees Iran Firing Back
articles.snippet: American officials believe a virus unleashed on an oil giant was a return volley in a conflict begun by the United States and Israel with software that targeted Iran’s centrifuges.
articles.abstract: American officials believe a virus unleashed on an oil giant was a return volley in a conflict begun by the United States and Israel with software that targeted Iran’s centrifuges.
articles.lead_paragraph: The hackers picked the one day of the year they knew they could inflict the most damage on the world’s most valuable company, Saudi Aramco.

articles.headline: Firms Don’t Share Consumer Optimism
articles.snippet: Many bellwether businesses have reported disappointing results and cut their outlook for future growth, but consumers remain buoyant.
articles.abstract: Many bellwether businesses have reported disappointing results and cut their outlook for future growth, but consumers remain buoyant.
articles.lead_paragraph: Consumers may finally be feeling more optimistic about the economy, but corporate America is not sharing the sentiment.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Nathaniel Popper

articles.headline: Standard of Living Is in the Shadows as Election Issue
articles.snippet: A decade-long stagnation in family incomes, a bedrock issue for the nation, has been caused by automation and globalization, among other factors not easily remedied in Washington.
articles.abstract: A decade-long stagnation in family incomes, a bedrock issue for the nation, has been caused by automation and globalization, among other factors not easily remedied in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Taxes and government spending. Health care. Immigration. Financial regulation.

articles.headline: New Federal Rules for Debt Collectors
articles.snippet: Collection agencies, whose sometimes aggressive tactics have earned them scrutiny, will come under supervision of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau beginning Jan. 2.
articles.abstract: Collection agencies, whose sometimes aggressive tactics have earned them scrutiny, will come under supervision of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau beginning Jan. 2.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Debt collection agencies, whose sometimes aggressive tactics have earned them scrutiny from consumer protection groups and state regulators, will come under federal supervision for the first time beginning Jan. 2, when the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau begins oversight.

articles.headline: Oil Refining’s Fortunes Rise
articles.snippet: Refining, once regarded as a low-margin, accident-prone part of the energy industry, is doing better in the United States in part because of cheaper natural gas and domestic crude oil.
articles.abstract: Refining, once regarded as a low-margin, accident-prone part of the energy industry, is doing better in the United States in part because of cheaper natural gas and domestic crude oil.
articles.lead_paragraph: THREE RIVERS, Tex. — The refinery business has long been the difficult stepchild of the oil industry, expensive to run, prone to accidents and a low-margin headache for executives who preferred drilling for gushers.
